article.headline: Loyola Marymnt 82, Portland 77
article.story: SANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- Steve Aggers had a gut feeling Sherman Gay would take over the game for Loyola Marymount, and the coach was right. Gay had 30 points and a career-high 15 rebounds to lead the Lions to an 82-77 comeback win over Portland in the first round of the West Coast Conference tournament Friday night. "All-league players elevate their game when the best is needed," Aggers said. "Our team just played harder in the second half. Our defense is what started it. Their matchup gave us fits in the first half." The Lions (15-13) rallied from an 11-point deficit in the second half to avenge two losses to the Pilots during the regular season and clinch their first winning season since 1996. They will play third-seeded Pepperdine on Saturday. Gay scored seven points late in the game, converting a three-point play with 4:01 left to pull the Lions within 71-69, a free throw with 3:18 to go and then a putback with his left hand less than 20 seconds later to tie the game at 72. He hit one free throw at 1:34 before Wes Wardrop's 3 with 1:02 remaining all but wrapped up the win. Gay was held to three points the last time these teams met, a 74-59 home win by Portland on Feb. 5. That came after Gay had gone off for 26 points in his team's 77-68 loss Dec. 4 in Los Angeles. He was inspired to do better this time. "I just go out and play my hardest and good things happen," Gay said. The 6-foot-7 forward came in averaging 15.7 points and 5.4 rebounds, the best production by a Loyola Marymount senior since the late Hank Gathers averaged 29.0 points and 10.8 rebounds in 1990 before collapsing during the Lions' WCC tournament game against Portland. Gathers died at age 23. Gay was 11-for-15 from the field and 8-of-15 from the foul line. The Lions shot 60 percent in the second half (15-for-25). Eugene Jeter scored 19 for Portland (11-17), which lost six of its final seven games and failed to win in the conference tournament for the eighth straight season. Dustin Geddis had 11 of his 13 points in the first half and played only five minutes in the second half because of foul trouble. He fouled out with 1:34 left. "I felt good about how the game was going. I thought we were in good shape," Portland coach Michael Holton said. "The second half we clearly didn't respond. We basically took a knock-out punch." Charles Brown added 17 points, six rebounds, five assists and a blocked shot for Loyola Marymount. Brown made a three-point play with 12:16 left to pull the Lions within 56-51 and spark the comeback. Portland was shooting 39.2 percent from the 3-point line, but went 5-for-14 from long range and shot 25 percent in the second half after a 57.1-percent first half. Geddis scored seven points, including back-to-back baskets, in a 12-6 run by the Pilots to end the first half and give them a 44-35 halftime lead.
